data manipulation.name: polars
data manipulation.tooltip: Best dataframe library around, for its combination of speed, lazy evaluation, support of many formats, and expressive syntax. Written in Rust and available for both Python and R. If you're a dplyr user, you may want to check out tidypolars, as well!

data manipulation.name: dplyr
data manipulation.tooltip: Verb-based approach to data manipulation for R. Operations can be chained in an extremely intuitive way. Ideal for data exploration or for tidying data before plotting.

data manipulation.name: tidyr
data manipulation.tooltip: Ideal companion to dplyr. I mainly use it for its pivot_* functions.

data manipulation.name: data.table
data manipulation.tooltip: Very fast R library for data manipulation with concise syntax. Well integrated within the R ecosystem and with no dependencies (i.e., reliable). Can even be used as a backend for dplyr!

data viz.name: ggplot2
data viz.tooltip: De-facto standard plotting library in R. Easy to use and with lots of extensions.

data viz.name: seaborn
data viz.tooltip: I hate matplotlib's syntax. Seaborn makes plotting on Python bearable.

data viz.name: plotnine
data viz.tooltip: Python library *heavily* inspired by ggplot2 (basically a port).

data viz.name: gephi
data viz.tooltip: Open-source software to visualize graphs and networks. Very useful for exploration, also thanks to its fast layout algorithms. There's also a (nicer) web-based version called Gephi Lite.

llms.name: ellmer
llms.tooltip: As official support for R is lackluster, this is a great library to interface with all kinds of model providers, both remote and local. It's also part of the tidyverse! Other R alternatives are tidyllm, mall, or ollamar and rollama (as ollama-only interfaces).

llms.name: adk
llms.tooltip: Python toolkit by Google to develop and deploy AI agents. Flexible, powerful, and well documented. An easier-to-start-with alternative is HuggingFace's smolagents, also for Python.

llms.name: ollama
llms.tooltip: Not a library per se, but a great tool to run and manage local LLMs. Runs in the background and exposes a REST API any other library can easily interface with.

other pkgs.name: igraph
other pkgs.tooltip: Imo, the best library for network analysis. Written in C and available for both R and Python.

other pkgs.name: cli
other pkgs.tooltip: R library to prettify console output. It can show formatted text, such as headings or bullet lists, and progress bars. Extremely easy to use, too!

other pkgs.name: httr2
other pkgs.tooltip: R library built on top of curl to work with web APIs. Amazing syntax and with many out-of-the-box features, such as automatic retries, parallel requests, and credentials handling. Wish something like it existed for Python.

other pkgs.name: graph-tool
other pkgs.tooltip: Network analysis toolkit for Python. Fast and feature-rich, though I can't quite get my head around its interface. I mostly use it for its implementation of stochastic block modeling.

other pkgs.name: markitdown
other pkgs.tooltip: Python utility to convert a wide range of formats into Markdown, particularly for use with LLMs or in other NLP pipelines.

aux tools.name: zed
aux tools.tooltip: Minimal (but powerful) code editor. Fast, has support for many languages, and has a number of great features out of the box that are also easy to use (such as remote devolopment).

aux tools.name: docker
aux tools.tooltip: Hard to summarize it if you don't know about it, but it's a containerization tool. It allows creating isolated environments (like virtual machines, but much lighter and faster) for reproducible projects.

aux tools.name: uv
aux tools.tooltip: Package and project manager for Python. Extremely fast and easy to use, it has replaced conda/pip/venv for me.

aux tools.name: renv
aux tools.tooltip: Package to create reproducible environments for R. Works great but doesn't also manage the R installation, just the packages. But can be used alongside docker. Alternatives are in development, such as rv (inspired by Python's uv) and rix (based on Nix).

aux tools.name: micromamba
aux tools.tooltip: This is a lightweight version of mamba, which is itself a rewrite of (the much slower) conda. Works great, but these days I tend to rely on uv.
